discussion.title: Custom objective questions
discussion.body:
EDIT: Resolved. I figured out the reason for the difference.
In my Julia helper's code, length(prediction) was 100 (correct, because I am trying to divide by the number of points, was 100).
While in my model's objective function, length(prediction) was 1.
So, in the model's objective function, I just changed length(prediction) to sizeof(prediction)[1].

Hi,

When I run the following objective function:
```
objective = """
import Pkg
Pkg.add("Roots")
Pkg.add("ForwardDiff")
Pkg.add("QuadGK")

using Roots
using ForwardDiff
using QuadGK
function eval_loss(tree, dataset::Dataset{T,L}, options)::L where {T,L}
    MAX_THRESHOLD_ALLOWED = 10000
    

    prediction, flag = eval_tree_array(tree, dataset.X, options)
    !flag && return L(Inf)
    
    num_points = length(prediction)
    
    for i in 1:num_points
        cur_expr_val = prediction[i]
        if (cur_expr_val > MAX_THRESHOLD_ALLOWED)
            return L(Inf)
        end
        if (cur_expr_val < 0)
            return L(Inf)
        end
    end
    
    
    
    
    # BELOW SECTION IS TO CHECK FOR IF THE GUESSED FUNCTION TAKES ON ANY POSITIVE INFINITY VALUES
    # OR NEGATIVE INFINITY VALUES ON THE DOMAIN X=[0, 1].
    
    
    # NOTE: reshape([x], 1, 1) should give same dimensions
    # as reshape([x;], 1, 1).
    # f(x) = x -> 1/(eval_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options))
    f(x) = 1 / ((eval_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options))[1][1])
    
    # fp(x) = ForwardDiff.derivative(f,float(x))
    fp(x) = ( -1 / ((eval_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options))[1][1])^2 * (eval_diff_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options, 1))[2][1])
    
    global found_a_recip_root = true
    global recip_roots = -3
    try
        global recip_roots = find_zero((f, fp), 0.3, Roots.Newton(), maxevals=100)
        #println("recip_roots is", recip_roots)
    catch
        global found_a_recip_root = false
        # "Convergence Failed"
    end
    
    # If the function f(x) represented by the tree "tree"
    # has a value f(x) close to positive infinity or negative infinity
    # when x is in [0, 1], then return L(Inf).
    if found_a_recip_root
        if (recip_roots >= 0 && recip_roots <= 1)
            return L(Inf)
        end
    end
    
    
    # BELOW SECTION IS TO CHECK FOR IF THE GUESSED FUNCTION TAKES ON ANY NEGATIVE VALUES OR ZERO VALUES
    # ON THE DOMAIN X=[0, 1].
    f(x) = ((eval_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options))[1][1])
    
    fp(x) = ((eval_diff_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options, 1))[2][1])
    
    global found_a_root = true
    global roots = -3
    try
        global roots = find_zero((f, fp), 0.3, Roots.Newton(), maxevals=100)
        #println("roots is", roots)
    catch
        global found_a_root = false
        # "Convergence Failed"
    end
    
    if found_a_root
        if (roots >= 0 && roots <= 1)
            println("found a root so returned L(Inf) and string rep of the tree was")
            println(string_tree(tree, options))
            return L(Inf)
        end
    end
    
    
    
    global integral = 1
    err = -3
    try
        my_tuple = quadgk(x -> (eval_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options))[1][1], 0, 1, rtol=0.01)
        global integral = my_tuple[1]
        global err = my_tuple[2]
    catch
        return L(Inf)
    end
    
    
    
    norm_constant = integral
    if (integral <= 0)
        println("integral was <=0")
        return L(Inf)
    end
    
    if (isinf(integral))
        #println("integral was Inf")
        return L(Inf)
    end
    
    actual_probs = (prediction) / norm_constant
    
    # length(actual_probs) equals length(prediction)
    
    # We really care about the EXPECTED VALUE OF L, where L = -1 * sum(log.(actual_probs)) / (length(prediction))
    # given that dataset.X is generated by the true probability distribution.
    # E(L) is really equal to the definite integral from x=0 to x=1 of ln(guessed_f(x)) * f_true(x) dx.
    # As num_points goes to +infinity, the variance of L becomes 0.
    
    final_loss = exp(-1 * sum(log.(actual_probs)) / (length(prediction)))
    #println("final_loss is ", final_loss)
    return final_loss
end
"""
```

and then I define the PySR model as:
```
model = PySRRegressor(
    niterations=20,  # < Increase me for better results
    binary_operators=["+", "*", "-", "/"],
    full_objective=objective,
    enable_autodiff=True,
    early_stop_condition = "f(loss, complexity) = (loss < 0.1)"
)
```

I define the dataset in Python as:
```
import numpy as np
X = np.random.rand(100, 1)
print(X.shape)
num_points = X.shape[0] # num_points is 100
y = 1000 * np.ones(num_points)
```

Then I run
```
model.fit(X, y)
```
(I do all this in a Python shell inside the MacBook terminal),
the final value of models has a equations_ of 9 equations (so 9 rows).
The model.equations_[8, :] (so the last equation found by the model "model") is:
complexity                                                      17
loss                                                       0.00174
score                                                     1.872243
equation         '(((1.4335294 / (x0 + 1.6759317)) + 0.6227007) / (0.21702437 - ((-1.312221 - (-0.2316349 / x0)) - x0)))
sympy_format     (0.6227007 + 1.4335294/(x0 + 1.6759317))/(x0 +...
lambda_format    PySRFunction(X=>(0.6227007 + 1.4335294/(x0 + 1...
Name: 8, dtype: object

However, when I run this exact equation using a Julia helper object ("jl"), I get a infinity value for the loss.
Specifically, I use the "jl" julia helper and I run:
```
jl.eval("""
# YOU CAN USE THIS CODE BLOCK TO TEST OUT THE VALUE OF THE CUSTOM OBJECTIVE FUNCTION

function eval_loss_real(tree, dataset, options)
    MAX_THRESHOLD_ALLOWED = 10000
    

    prediction, flag = eval_tree_array(tree, dataset, options)
    !flag && return L(Inf)
    
    num_points = length(prediction)
    
    for i in 1:num_points
        cur_expr_val = prediction[i]
        if (cur_expr_val > MAX_THRESHOLD_ALLOWED)
            println("prediction was greater than MAX_THRESHOLD_ALLOWED")
            return (Inf)
        end
        if (cur_expr_val < 0)
            println("prediction was less than 0")
            return (Inf)
        end
    end
    
    
    
    
    # BELOW SECTION IS TO CHECK FOR IF THE GUESSED FUNCTION TAKES ON ANY POSITIVE INFINITY VALUES
    # OR NEGATIVE INFINITY VALUES ON THE DOMAIN X=[0, 1].
    
    
    # NOTE: reshape([x], 1, 1) should give same dimensions
    # as reshape([x;], 1, 1).
    # f(x) = x -> 1/(eval_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options))
    f(x) = 1 / ((eval_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options))[1][1])
    
    # fp(x) = ForwardDiff.derivative(f,float(x))
    fp(x) = ( -1 / ((eval_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options))[1][1])^2 * (eval_diff_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options, 1))[2][1])
    
    global found_a_recip_root = true
    global recip_roots = -3
    try
        global recip_roots = find_zero((f, fp), 0.3, Roots.Newton(), maxevals=100)
        #println("recip_roots is", recip_roots)
    catch
        global found_a_recip_root = false
        # "Convergence Failed"
    end
    
    # If the function f(x) represented by the tree "tree"
    # has a value f(x) close to positive infinity or negative infinity
    # when x is in [0, 1], then return L(Inf).
    if found_a_recip_root
        if (recip_roots >= 0 && recip_roots <= 1)
            return (Inf)
        end
    end
    
    
    # BELOW SECTION IS TO CHECK FOR IF THE GUESSED FUNCTION TAKES ON ANY NEGATIVE VALUES OR ZERO VALUES
    # ON THE DOMAIN X=[0, 1].
    f(x) = ((eval_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options))[1][1])
    
    fp(x) = ((eval_diff_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options, 1))[2][1])
    
    global found_a_root = true
    global roots = -3
    try
        global roots = find_zero((f, fp), 0.3, Roots.Newton(), maxevals=100)
        #println("roots is", roots)
    catch
        global found_a_root = false
        # "Convergence Failed"
    end
    
    if found_a_root
        if (roots >= 0 && roots <= 1)
            println("found a root so returned L(Inf) and string rep of the tree was")
            println(string_tree(tree, options))
            return (Inf)
        end
    end
    
    
    
    global integral = 1
    err = -3
    try
        my_tuple = quadgk(x -> (eval_tree_array(tree, reshape([Float32(x)], 1, 1), options))[1][1], 0, 1, rtol=0.01)
        global integral = my_tuple[1]
        global err = my_tuple[2]
    catch
        return (Inf)
    end
    
    
    
    norm_constant = integral
    if (integral <= 0)
        println("integral was <=0")
        return (Inf)
    end
    
    if (isinf(integral))
        println("integral was Inf")
        return (Inf)
    end
    
    actual_probs = (prediction) / norm_constant
    
    # length(actual_probs) equals length(prediction)
    
    # We really care about the EXPECTED VALUE OF L, where L = -1 * sum(log.(actual_probs)) / (length(prediction))
    # given that dataset.X is generated by the true probability distribution.
    # E(L) is really equal to the definite integral from x=0 to x=1 of ln(guessed_f(x)) * f_true(x) dx.
    # As num_points goes to +infinity, the variance of L becomes 0.
    
    final_loss = exp(-1 * sum(log.(actual_probs)) / (length(prediction)))
    #println("final_loss is ", final_loss)
    return final_loss
end

options = SymbolicRegression.Options(
    binary_operators=[+, *, /, -, ^],
    unary_operators=[cos, sin],
    enable_autodiff=true
)

num_points = 100

x = rand(Beta(3, 2), num_points)
x = reshape(x, 1, num_points)
x = Float32.(x)

x1 = Node(;feature=1)

#tree = -0.828202055*(x1*x1) + x1 - 0.14140837

# tree = x1 + x1
# tree = x1

# Final_loss was 0.67114264 (when I allowed it to not return Infinity, and used a norm_constant of 1).
#tree = -0.094332316551433*x1 + 1.7470982*x1/(1.67670228876569*x1 - 0.282760834105208)

# On model.equations_, the loss was 0.001739
tree = 0.21702437*(0.6227007 + 1.4335294/(x1 + 1.6759317))/(x1 + 1.52924537 - 0.2316349/x1)

tree = Node{Float32}(tree)

println(string_tree(tree, options))

my_loss = eval_loss_real(tree, x, options)
println("FINAL LOSS was ", my_loss)
""")

```
The output of running this jl.eval() was:
```
WARNING: Method definition (::Main.var"#f#52"{tree, options})(Any) in module Main at none:26 overwritten at none:69.
WARNING: Method definition (::Main.var"#fp#53"{tree, options})(Any) in module Main at none:29 overwritten at none:71.
WARNING: Method definition (::Main.var"#f#56"{tree, options})(Any) in module Main at none:169 overwritten at none:196.
WARNING: Method definition (::Main.var"#fp#57"{tree, options})(Any) in module Main at none:172 overwritten at none:198.
((0.21702437 * (0.6227007 + (1.4335294 / (x1 + 1.6759317)))) / ((x1 + 1.5292454) - (0.2316349 / x1)))
prediction was less than 0
FINAL LOSS was Inf
```

And it's not just this one time that I ran model.fit(X, y) that I noticed a difference between the model's reported loss of the model's last-found function and the usually-more correct outputted value of passing the model's last-found function into a Julia objective function manually and manually running the jl.eval() of that Julia code.

Another question: What would "WARNING: Method definition (::Main.var"#f#52"{tree, options})(Any) in module Main at none:26 overwritten at none:69." mean, what are its negative consequences, and how do I change my code to avoid this warning message?

nodes.body: You can get the number of rows from `dataset.n`. Alternatively using `size(dataset.X, 2)`. You donâ€™t want to use `length` because it will count all elements if there are multiple features.
With so much Julia customization, it might be easier to work on this directly from Julia? i.e., with SymbolicRegression.jl?
